--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrot=
e:
>
> Christofer, it's an interesting idea but I think it may be 
difficul=
t 
> to implement in practice because of the nonlinear relationship 
among =

> different components of the solution.  That is, just because some 
> thi=
ngs change or are updated more than others during learning does 
> not impl=
y that they should continue to do so or even that it was a 
> good idea in =
the first place (because the problem might be 
> deceptive).  It's a pretty=
 complicated topic but I think the 
> fundamental issue is that evolutionar=
y computation is effective in 
> part because it avoids trying to excplicit=
ly assign credit to the 
> separate parts of a solution.  So when we move t=
o trying to extract 
> explicit information about what belongs with what, w=
e are somewhat 
> undoing this implicit appeal.
> 
> Nevertheless, the idea=
 that solutions need some kind of modularity 
> or at least a pattern behin=
d them makes sense.  It's just the 
> approach that is the tricky issue.  H=
ave you taken a look at 
> HyperNEAT?  It is able to evolve networks with l=
arge-scale patterns 
> that can be modular to varying degrees.
> 
> ken
> 
=

n@> wrote:

ler sub 
problems

hat you can tell which neurons were performing well 
in

tc)

 close to each other have a higher probability to form a

modular.=

ing

ath and when you are painting, different
